title: How many total cases of COVID-19 will be reported in Orange County, Florida, as of 30 July 2020?
preds: I don’t think it would change the outcome, but Florida will shut down testing tomorrow ...  https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/07/29/896895245/florida-will-pause-coronavirus-testing-due-to-impending-storm

This is going to be a very close call.  Check the stats on this link... https://www.google.com/search?q=covid+19+cases+orange+county+florida&rlz=1C1GCEA_enBR814BR814&oq=covid+19+cases+orange+county+florida&aqs=chrome..69i57j69i60.7898j0j7&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8       The current number is 28,190... according to the link provided.  Around 24 hours "to go" on the clock.
Would require both a spike that was higher than any recent spike and another day of significantly higher than recent average numbers. Not actually 0% but rounded to closest %
28191 the day before the end. This one is a safe bet now.

Only two days remaining in the question and upwards of 2,000 cases are required to cross 30,000, which is more than 1,000 each day. When the average of the last days has dropped from ~600 to ~400. I expect this to land at 28,500-29,000. Leaving 2% chance of a blast of 1,500 cases happening one of these days, causing a surprise.
There would need to be 2180 cases in 2 days for >30k to be reached. The 7 day average is 540 and has been hovering around there for awhile now, so this seems quite unlikely.
Update on latest daily new cases
If the current trend continues, or even increases 50% over the next 3 days, then cases will be just below 30k.
7 day average = 538. Average for the next 3 days tor each 30k = 869.
current rate of new daily infection would indicate that 30,000 will not be reached

Considering current count of about 27,400.  Most likely they will fall just under 30,000, but I think it is still possible that they go just over.  Looking at Orange Co FL covid site (https://www.orangecountyfl.net/EmergencySafety/Coronavirus/COVID19Snapshot.aspx#.Xx9k5C1q2fA), they report 8405 cases over 14 days, which is about 600 cases daily.  With 2 days left, they are likely to log about another 1200 cases.  It is possible that they log more, but unlikely that it will be more than double the number of daily cases compared to the previous 14 day period.  Still, being a tourist locale with places open to visit, there is a possibility of an asymptomatic superspreader event, albeit smallish.
Couple of days to go at the cusp of 27k now — seems unlikely it will surpass 30k, but leaving a 1% chance for an unforeseen jump.

3 days left. 27,393 total cases reported as of today. 869 per day needed to exceed 30k. 538 average over the last 7 days. Even if each of the next three days are 1.5x the 7 day average, the total will be below 30k (29,814).

Currently at about 27,000 and trending at about 600 per day (https://www.orangecountyfl.net/EmergencySafety/Coronavirus/COVID19Snapshot.aspx#.Xx79LJ5KiHs). In agreement with @aaronedwardolson on final numbers
Avg. cases/day over the past 7 days were about 100 lower than the previous 7. Using the past 7 day average, the total looks like it will be between 29K-30K.

Daily update of cases for yesterday was ~600 cases. Hitting 30k by 30 July now requires 755 daily new cases on average, which becomes less likely than before. Adjusting towards more in the lower bracket.
Still close. Only a few days left, daily numbers are coming down. But one spike could push it over 30k
Both the Florida state and Orange county seem to have reached peaked and trending slightly downwards. I am not expecting any sudden increase in the numbers over next few days.
Going to 100% on bin4 to correct for the fact that I've been spending more time protesting than forecasting this week, and kind of forgot about this one.

As @Dogopotamus noted the average needed to reach 30k (755) is over 200 cases greater than what the current 7 day average is (528). I would add that even if there was a one day spike of 1400 cases, if the other 3 days kept with the 7 day average then 30k cases would not be reached. So it would take a sustained spike to break 30k, which seems unlikely with the recent decline in cases.

4 days left. 26,980 total cases reported as of today. 755 per day needed to exceed 30k. 528 average over the last 7 days. Running out of days to pick up a data dump or spike large enough to take it over 30k.

Thanks to catches from @tmcgraw and @Dogopotamus, realized I had the incorrect estimation duration. Based on the update timing, it looks like the 29th will be the last set of data available on the 30th. With that in mind, based on current data, the average will need to be 712 for the next 5 days.  Looking back on the dataset for the month, the longest Orange has gone without a spike in cases from a data dump or testing backlog has been about a week. Right now we are at 10 days. We should expect a spike, but if that spike is at similar levels as previous (around 1300), it will still require an average of around 550 for the remaining days. This seems plausible, but really depends on a spike day coming through. The processing of testing isn't much clearer from when I last looked at the news on this. I wonder if the clump of results is being delayed due to the difficulty with private labs I noted in my last post. [1] I am going to swing to the 2nd highest bucket for these reasons. Will keep an eye out for that spike. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1089274

Adjustment due to progression/update. As of today morning July 26th, cases are 26,558. For it to cross 30,000 an average of 688 per day would be required. This is looking like roughly the average of the recent days, therefore equally likely to land just below or just above 30,000.
Difference is that the curve shape in Orange County FL suggests that the peak is behind us, therefore the days forward I expect confirmed cases lower than, rather than higher than the average. For this I put extra weight at the lower bracket. It will be marginal either way.

Dashboard has it as of 24 July. So up to 6 days worth of data could be added by end of day July 30. Would require 635 positives per day. This is a bit above the recent average. However, looks to be overdue for a positive case spike (caused by data dump or bulk return of tests) so that could push it over 30k.

Current case number is 26.559 and there are 5 days left. This means that the 30000 bracket needs 688 cases a day. Most case numbers for the recent weeks posted in the comments look smaller. But data might get delayed on the weekend, such that we see a lot more cases on monday?

The stats may sneak in under 30,000 ending 2359hrs on 30 July. Link https://www.google.com/search?q=orange+county+florida+current+covid+statistics&rlz=1C1GCEA_enBR814BR814&oq=orange+county+florida+current+covid+statistics&aqs=chrome..69i57.10352j0j4&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8  Hedging is good even if you are not Ray Dalio or one of the nerds on Netflix Billionaires.  However, One of the problems for me, and perhaps others, is that forecasters do not know how the system mathematically penalizes forecasters for "hedging"  Perhaps GJP's version of Nate Silver can offer some guidance. Also the graphics need green to offset the blues that are so close together.

508 cases per day are required for the remainder of the month to hit 30k. The last week of resident data is: 7/17	471
7/18	739
7/19	340
7/20	419
7/21	678
7/22	551
7/23	686 Which averages to 555, with a median of 551. While this certainly looks like a downward trend, as a number of others report (@Rickburger, @Bobbiekar52) testing is lagging, and there are a bunch of other issues around a few labs reporting 100% positive results [1], which may slow reporting down as the labs are held to account. I'm of the feeling that we will continue to see around 500 - 600 cases a day in Orange County. I'm putting a small amount in the 25 - 30k bin as a hedge. [1] https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/florida-labs-busted-covid/

There is talk of plateau. But testing and getting results can be slow ... link   still a week to https://www.clickorlando.com/news/local/2020/07/23/significant-covid-19-outbreak-reported-at-assisted-living-facility-in-orange-county/

6 days left. 25,952 total cases reported as of today. 675 per day needed to exceed 30k. 582 average over the last 7 days. I think this will end up reported between 29,500-29,999 cases on the 30th unless the state improves its processing time for tests before then.

Given that this Only going until  30th I am opting to put this in highly likely for the 25,000-30,000. Orange County would have to average over 675 new cases per day to be over 30,000 and they have been averaging between 550-625 per day.

Things are getting close to the wire. I am going to drop to 50/50. The final number will be completely based on whether Florida fixes testing issues, and whether the thousands of tests that have been taken are processed and reported by the county/state.  While the "official number" may not go over 30,000, I feel affirmed in my original estimate of how this will spread.  https://www.tampabay.com/news/health/2020/07/24/florida-adds-record-high-coronavirus-hospitalizations-12000-plus-cases/
The daily report of new coronavirus cases may not reflect what was found in the past 24 hours because of testing backlogs. In an effort to remedy these delays, Gov. Ron DeSantis has said he’ll cut ties with labs that don’t turn around tests fast enough. 
Florida has been averaging more than 11,000 cases a day since mid-July, with the number of tests processed on each day often fluctuating. Some days about 67,000 tests have been processed, and others have had more than 115,000.

I might be trying to pinpoint too well the number of cases for 30 of July, but it is worth trying. Right now we have: current cases = 25254 and during the last few days, the weekly increases in cases have been 44(day) weekly cases: 4666  Growth: 1.08411 new cases: 526
45(day) weekly cases: 5645  Growth: 1.36122 new cases: 1379
46(day) weekly cases: 5842  Growth: 1.44927 new cases: 742
47(day) weekly cases: 5839  Growth: 1.7482 new cases: 473
48(day) weekly cases: 5225  Growth: 1.3285 new cases: 739
49(day) weekly cases: 4634  Growth: 1.0323 new cases: 340
50(day) weekly cases: 4618  Growth: 1.01161 new cases: 419
51(day) weekly cases: 4769  Growth: 1.02207 new cases: 677
52(day) weekly cases: 3937  Growth: 0.697431 new cases: 547 where day 1 is 1st on June. Right now there is a week left, and it is not clear which is the weekly number of cases as there is a lot of noise. However it is probably somewhere between 4000 and 5500, which together with the 25254 cases we have, leads us to a projection of 29254 to 30754, which is pretty close to a 50-50 situation (however I slightly increase the probability of the lower bucket, as I think that the 4000-5000 range is more likely). What I did not check is something really obvious: check the evolution of cases in all of Florida, as to be able to predict the growth factor in the weekly new cases: if it is already falling, this will indicate that the same thing should happen in the Orange county and thus the probability of the 25-30K bucket will be much higher than the 30K+ bucket.
As of 7/22, there are 25,000 cases, with about 10,000 new cases every day. It seems highly likely there will be more than 30,000 cases by July 30.
Considering current total count over 25K and its a hot spot for tourists.
7 days left. 25,254 total cases as of today. 678 per day needed to exceed 30k. 562 average over the last 7 days. Looking less likely now unless there is another spike.
Already over 25000.  Expect it will get worse before it gets better

Recent downward trend in daily new cases.
https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/96dd742462124fa0b38ddedb9b25e429
Tweeking my forecast a little as todays numbers were below 600.  I still believe that it will be close but likely just under 30k

The outcome will be very close as of the most recent daily counts, so it's likely I will review my current review of my former review once more... ;-)
Basically, I assume testing is very low in Orange county, FL, at the moment. One single day with more than 10k tests and more than 1,200 new confirmed cases will change the whole calculus and will render a total case count of less than 30k cases by 30 July impossible.
I think such a high daily value is very likely in the next few days, thus I see no other option than to switch back to the last bin.

Per previous forecasts I calculate an average of about 664 new cases/day since 7/3/20.  If that multi-day average were to hold 30,000+ cases would be likely by July 30th. (Nine days left.) ..But reported new cases over the last few days have generally dropped below that estimate, so trying to hedge/adjust the forecast some.  https://www.wesh.com/article/orange-county-hospitilizations-covid-19/33373391

Florida is still lagging in test results.  https://www.tampabay.com/news/health/2020/07/22/florida-adds-140-coronavirus-deaths-and-9785-new-cases/ https://www.wesh.com/article/florida-coronavirus-cases-july-22/33392610# https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/experience/america/theme-parks/2020/07/20/disney-world-face-mask-requirement-tightened-no-eating-while-walking/5472988002/
Nevermind, miscalculated on my last forecast.
Low case days on 7/19 and 7/20; increased my number for the 25K-30K bracket. https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/96dd742462124fa0b38ddedb9b25e429

Cases in Florida have grown in the last month or so, however the rate of growth in reported cases seems to be stabilizing a bit in the last few days, but only for now. Data is trending towards close to 28-29 thousand at the end of the month and a slight increase in the rate of growth will put the numbers over 30k by the end of the month. Case growth in other states can also tie up testing resources, slowing confirmation of cases everywhere. Also, unfortunately the data is being routed through a political faction instead of the CDC, allowing for the numbers to be skewed lower. This all does not include reported probable or likely cases, which in any larger outbreak tends to be much higher than the number of identified cases.
current pace of cases will be close to if not over 30,000
9 days left. 24,011 total cases as of today. 666 per day needed to exceed 30k. 660.3 average over the last 7 days.
Another low case day. 7 day average is now 660, and the average needed to reach 30k for the next 9 days is 666. Reducing my odds of >30k accordingly.
County cases have slightly lowered the last couple of days. https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/96dd742462124fa0b38ddedb9b25e429

Sorry made a keyboarding error. Latest Google info TODAY (which means yesterday's stats) shows 23,583 cases with 10 or 11 days in month remaining (depending on how you choose to define "days")... Link https://www.google.com/search?q=covid+cases+orange+county+flordia&rlz=1C1GCEA_enBR814BR814&oq=covid+cases+orange+county+flordia&aqs=chrome..69i57.9184j0j4&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8 Official data does not agree with these stats, however...

Latest Google info TODAY (which means yesterday's stats) shows 23,583 cases with 10 or 11 days in month remaining (depending on how you choose to define "days")... Link  https://www.google.com/search?q=covid+cases+orange+county+flordia&rlz=1C1GCEA_enBR814BR814&oq=covid+cases+orange+county+flordia&aqs=chrome..69i57.9184j0j4&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8    Official data does not agree with these stats, however...

11 reporting days left, leaving an average of 580ish per day to hit 30k.  Last 7 day average is 665.  It is going to be bang on the border line as the daily average has backed off slightly and therefore might be expected to continue that way.

Only 340 cases reported today. In all of Florida the number of tests and % positive tests have remained steady [1], so this is unexpected given Orlando's recent sustained spikes. This drop is likely an outlier, but the 7 day average is back down to 663. The average needs to be below 642 for there to be <30k cases on the 30th. I may have updated too aggressively towards >30k, although I still think it will be hit. [1] https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/testing/individual-states/florida
Not convinced with the current trend that it will be over 30K. Looks like right on the line. I'll update closer to the date.

Just following the crowd...
(This is necessary... I'm bad at C19 forecasting.)

It is very close, but I think the case count (which needs to average 600 from here by my math). will come down. I note that testing is showing 11% positive and it looks like 40,000 test per week . So in 11 days that would add less than the 8000 required

13 days of reporting left.  22518 cases means and average of 575 per day will hit 30k.  With the past week averaging over 800 per day, this now looks likely.  But the average has hovered at this level for a couple of weeks now in Orange County so one would expect any lockdown and behaviour change to start taking effect.  Upping forecast, but it’s still not 100pc.

Currently Orange County has 22,518 cases, they will need to average 576 new cases per day, for the next 13 days to exceed 30,000. I have been tracking the covid19 numbers since March, Florida is in the middle of a surge, but they have not peaked. Given how the numbers have risen, I expect a peak within the next 7-10 days. How long it lasts will depend on what actions they take...and they really should be considering shutting down now.

Only 473 cases today but the 7 day average is still 834. Average cases from now until the 30th need to drop below 624 for there to be <30k total cases. With the recent sustained spike this seems unlikely.
I think it might be riiiiiight on the line.
At 13 days to go 615 addition cases needed per day.  It’s going to be close to the 30,000 mark.  Nudging probability of over 30k up a bit more

7 day average is at 834 - in order to be under 30k cases by the 30th average cases will need to drop below 611. Only 5 days ago the 7 day average was hovering at 600, but given the sustained increase in cases we can now be very confident that this spike is not an anomaly (2 day spikes had been seen in the past).
21299 yesterday, 22049 today. Florida has been patchy on reporting, but was 16,148 a week ago, so averaged 843 a day this week. Only needs 10 days at current rate to hit 30,000.

https://occovid19.ochealthinfo.com/
Today they have 27,904 cases and the daily is 873. This is still ramping up so they will get +38k.

Big spike today, 7 day average is now 806, and only 622 cases per day are needed to reach 30k by July 30th.  Making a big adjustment to my forecast based on this, as I thought I would have to if cases rose.

Currently at 21,299 cases, Orange County is 8701 cases away from hitting 30,000. There will need to be an average of 622 new cases over the next 14 days to exceed 30,000. Most days average about 500-550 news cases a day with one or two days exceeding that average (1390 new cases today.) Cases do seem to be ramping up though, so I am edging closer to the over 30,000 mark.

"Whoa...": https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/96dd742462124fa0b38ddedb9b25e429 ..By my estimate Orange Co. is now averaging 709 cases/day over the past 13 days (since 7/3/20). (Per source above.)  Even if that average drops to 600/day that would put them very close to 30,000 cases. (600 cases/day times 14 reporting days left = estimated 8400 new cases. There are currently 21,299 reported cases.)
I've made a mess of this Question, shouldn't have departed as easily from basepoint. Tough!

19337 on 14th to 21299 today. They are working on fixing their testing turnaround times ... and hopefully doing better at accurately reporting testing results. Going back to 100%, I had lowered it with the long turnaround times.  It WILL be over 30,000. The only question is whether it will be reported over this number.

Using this data for total cases for Orange County Florida: https://usafacts.org/visualizations/coronavirus-covid-19-spread-map/state/florida/county/orange-county I got this fits: 
50 base days - Exp fit (97.3%) -> 50K
50 base days - Poly fit (99.8%) -> 37K
30 base days - Exp fit (99.3%)  -> 32K
30 base days - Poly fit (99.3%) -> 32K
30 base days - Lin fit (98.9%)   -> 28K Less radical numbers then my prior forecast, still almost all above 30,000
Real difference is if trend breaks. There are signs of it: 30 days based projection is less then 50 days based one.
But I would stay with 100 for now.

Florida data is known day by day. Since we forecast 2 weeks forward lets use 30 days as a basis.
Fitting exponential curve to last 30 days of John Hopkins University data we get about 650,000 of total cases for Florida. Fit seems accurate with 99.7% R-squared July 4th Orange County had 1000 cases. Florida at the same day had 11,500 reported.  This would give a ratio of 1 to 11. Orange county population in 2019 is 1.4M vs 21M in Florida which is ratio 1/15. Per Google  search with reference to NYT on 07-16-2020 total Orange County Florida 19,908 vs 302,000 Florida it would give a ration of 1/15.  So, Using 1/11 ratio as a middle ground we get 60,000
1/15 results in 43,000,  Appreciate @SE_Meyer calling my earlier error in Orange County Fl population
I  can update it later
Adjusting down as I think there's a decent chance the number will be around 30,000 on the nose.

Around 5000 cases being added on a weekly basis. I would think that the trend will hold (at least, if not increase). This makes it a play between the last 2 buckets - b/w 25k and 30k OR more than 30k.  Baselining with
b/w 25k and 30k     - 55%
more than 30k        - 45% Will look and revise as needed.
Just a time and testing issue.

15 July @ 20k.  15 more days.  To stay under 25k need to average 300 new cases per day.  Recent average approx 500 per day.  Seems unlikely to happen.  Average of 650 per day to get to 30k cases.  Am upping probabity of higher ranges
Following Covid-19 cases here: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/florida-coronavirus-cases.html#cases Will update prediction after I find some good weekly data.
I think the crowd is on target.

Only 440 cases reported today, a big drop from the past 2 days. Yesterday I wrote that we would see in the next few days whether the spike would sustain or drop back down (as it has done twice before) [1]. Current 7 day average is 658 cases, which would result in <30k cases by Jul 30th if it continued. I think the crowd is forecasting too high on >30k, but then again we haven't seen the result of Disney World opening yet. [1] https://usafacts.org/visualizations/coronavirus-covid-19-spread-map/state/florida/county/orange-county

Rolling 7-day average continues to increase and is now close to the daily number needed to push above 30k total. The measures currently in place to control spread are not enough, in my opinion, to reduce new cases below a daily average of 664 in the next 16 days. If new cases on the 18th or 19th exceed 1500, that will be a good indicator that they’ll hit 30k by the 30th.

Young median age of cases, positive test results at over 10%. I think things will continue a few weeks yet.
It's looking close to the 30,000 break, but I'm edging onto the higher side at 29,000 - 32,000

19337 today from 18937 yesterday. Only 440 new cases. 16 days.  Florida overall saw a decrease, but the holiday weekend willbegin to show up later this week.   Special note - some locations in our state have gone Back to symptomatic  testing only. If Florida does this, it will not reduce the number of cases but will reduce the number of reported cases.  I am, at this point, lowering my forecast (for the first time) because I am concerned testing issues will come into play.
I could cite reams and reams of statistics as well as articles and opinion pieces, but the state is a full on shit show and it shows no movement to calm down anytime soon.

Revising this after the recent couple of days explosion in confirmed incidents in Orange County FL.
Low bookend: 500 new per day x 17 days remaining in July = 8.500 + 18.639 = 27.139 total cases on 30th July.
High bookend: 900 new per day x 17 days = 15.300 + 18.639 = 33.939 total by 30th July.
The bracket split is at 30.000 cases so my bookends are unevenly distributed on each side, with more of my distribution falling in the high bracket. I am at the beach right now so not in the mood to apply standard deviation calcs (also I believe the exponential curve would be slightly more complicated than normal distribution) so I will approximate the probabilities by saying 60% of my distribution is above the 30.000 limit.

As of today July 14th the last two days have seen an explosion of confirmed infections which makes me revise my estimate upwards to:
Low bookend: 500 new per day x 17 days = 8.500 + 18639 = 27.139 at 30 July.
High bookend: 900 new per day x 17 days = 15.300 + 18.639 = 33.939 at 30 July.
The bracket in the question splits at 30.000, leaving more to the high side than to the low side.
Hence I assign 60% to the >30.000 bracket.

As of 2019, the County had 1.4 mil. people. Per Johns Hopkins, they are at 18,000 cases or so as of 7/13/2020. In the past day, the number of new cases tripled, from about 400 to 1200.  The number of NEW cases in Florida has gone up about every week as: 4600, 9500, 11,000, 15,000.  Based on the website for FL DPH, that County has had 18,937 total cases as of 7/13/2020.  I think this question is asking how many total cases since the beginning of testing for SARS-CoV-2.  I am very sure there will be a total of more than 30,000 cases. There is a lag time of 1-2 weeks for the cases to show up after exposure. By the time mid-July policy has taken effect around 7/27/2020, probably the number of new cases will be increasing by a factor of 1.25 or 1.5, or even 2 (i.e. doubling) on a daily basis. By the time people regret it, it will be too late to get it down again.  The only way I think it'll be <30K is if they run out of swabs or reagent.  Mathematically speaking, this is what it looks like when a stampede of horses leaves the barn. The big bummer: It's a small world after all. Source: 
https://bao.arcgis.com/covid-19/jhu/county/12095.html

In my comment yesterday I calculated that daily cases would have to be >666 on average for there to be >30k cases by July 30th. There were 1300 new cases yesterday and 900 today, and the 7 day average is 647. There have been 2-3 day spikes that have settled back down, so I am conservatively updating towards >30k. [1] If new cases remain high in the coming days I will update more liberally towards >30k and away from 25-30k. [1] https://usafacts.org/visualizations/coronavirus-covid-19-spread-map/state/florida/county/orange-county
Based on current total case count and average new cases each day, at a minimum total  cases will be at 25,000 and given recent spike in cases will surpass 30,000
At ~18k today after a grim record setting day for Florida. Notching back to a more nuanced forecast.
650/day will get them to 30k by the 30th. Seven day average is about 639 and increasing.

Useful links:
Number of cases in last 14 days: https://bao.arcgis.com/covid-19/jhu/county/12095.html
Florida Coronavirus Map and Case Count by Counties: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/florida-coronavirus-cases.html#county
COVID-19 United States Cases by County - Johns Hopkins Coronavirus Resource Center: https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/us-map
16630 on July 11. 18937 today.  Accelerating. At the current rate it will be over 25,000 by the end of this week. Still hoping I am wrong.

With a median age of infections at 34yrs, perhaps the perceived risk to health is not being considered as highly. However there are a number of indicators in the media that more needs to be done; Fauci, Trump wearing a mask etc. So I think the case numbers will continue to increase, but at around 10-15% per week in the short term.

Average daily cases for the past 7 days is ~600. ~500 excluding today (1371 new cases). There are 18k total cases. A reasonable lower bound would be 500*18+18000 = 27k. For total cases to be <25k, daily cases would have to be <400 for the next 18 days. For total cases to be >30k, daily cases would have to be >666 for the next 18 days. Given the current daily case average and the fact that Florida is continuing to open (including Disney World), this is entirely possible. However, daily totals have only exceeded 666 four times so far. https://usafacts.org/visualizations/coronavirus-covid-19-spread-map/state/florida/county/orange-county

Bumping this up. Yesterday was at 1.3k cases, giving a total of 18k [1]. This will be increasing fast, especially with places like Disney opening [2]. [1] https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/96dd742462124fa0b38ddedb9b25e429
[2] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/11/walt-disney-world-orlando-reopening-during-covid-19-how-to-stay-safe.html

Edging closer to the over 30,000 cases. Sunday’s are typically low reporting days and Florida recorded over 15,000 new cases. Orange County has 1371 new cases today for a total of 18,001 total cases. Orange County will still need to average over 667 new cases a day to reach 30,000, I think it’s likely, but you never know.

Still working with the assumption that there are 18 more reporting days for this question after today, 7/12/20. County cases are recently increasing. By my count 5,923 new cases have been reported since 7/3/30. (12,078 cases on 7/3.) 5923 divided by the last eight reporting days now = an average of 740 (recent) new cases/day. As one hypothetical example 18 remaining reporting days times an average of 700 new cases/day adds an estimated 12,600 cases to the present total of 18,001.  600 cases/day adds 10,800 new cases. 500/day adds 9.000... I took a second look at Orange county data on cases, demographics, geography and testing. While Orange with its 1.939mn inhabitants (est. as of 2019) represents about 9.03% of all FL inhabitants (21.478mn est. as of 2019), testing statistics suggests that in the mid-east region of the FL peninsular counties have been under-tested. As of 09 July 2020, of all 2.424mn "Total People Tested" only 6.89% or 167,133 of the total have undergeone a test in Orange. The "Awaiting testing" number of 195, or 1.2%, appears to be low to me, but I'd like to find out what it means exactly, and whether these cases usually have a higher positivity than average, whether they are supposed to become "inconclusive" in the end (no tests of this category so far in Orange), or whether their results just came in late to be included into daily reports. As of 10 July this figure increased to 230, but I still tend to interpret, that testing in Orange runs in a rather orderly procedure, compared to other FL counties (Miami) or states.
The under-testing in Orange may be a point of uncertainty for future cases increases, but currently it does not seem worrisome as the reason may lie, as I mentioned before, in worse-than-average outbreaks in metro areas of Jacksonville, Tampa and especially Miami with the respective counties surrounding them.
In contrast, Orange has a below-average positivity rate of 9.8% as of 10 July 2020 (9.66% as of 09 July), so the health admin may not see the necessity to test there and will route available supplies and lab capacities to the red-flagged areas. This is reasonable, but risky at the same time since an outbreak will not indicate its start beforehand, and if you start to increase testing late, as with Texas, it may be too late. However, Orange county is situated in the middle of and with borders to Semilnole (4,083 cases; 8.8% total positivity rate), Brevard (3,237; 5.5%), Osceola (3,861; 11.3%), Lake (2,394; 5.7%); Polk is close and rather heavily infected (6,983; 11.4%), but does not have a common border with Orange, it seems, so my conclusion here is that a worsening of the outbreak in Orange from transporting the virus into Orange from neighboring counties is slim, it is more likely that the virus will migrate from greater Orlando area out into less infected areas and counties.
Furthermore, looking at the "Cases by Zip Code" tab you can see that the virus occurrence is not yet evenly spread, and that e.g. within Polk the most affected area is the Zips in the Winter Haven-area, while to the northeast, towards Orange and Orlando, there are still some Zips, which are hardly or less densely affected. Inland, inter-county traffic, which may be reduced, may be one reason, while coastal areas such as around Tampa, Jacksonville, and West Palm Beach down to Miami are highly affected maybe due to holiday season, spring break aftermath, snowbirds or other inter-state traffic. In all, if figures will remain low (cases below 700 per day ; positivity rate below 10%) for at least five more days, I will be confident that Orange has avoided the worst, and the outcome of this question will be below 30,000. However, if positivity rate spikes even in Orange, which the recent increase heralds and which spells trouble, it's time to stay alert.

The Orlando Sentinel reports that as of 11 July, (figures thru 10 July) Orange county has 16,630 cases. The  Sentinel reports that between July 9 and 10, there were 482 new cases of Covid-19 in Orange county. If we are predicting how many cases will be reported as of 30 July (that means through the 29th as the statistical reporting day), that's 19 days "from now." So lets split the difference and say 20.  I am just taking 482 cases per day and bumping it up 10 percent considering the crowds and activities going on, which equals 530 new cases per day, times 20 days, which is 10,500 new cases.   I add that to the current 16,630 reported by the Sentinel, and my "best guess for now is 27230.  But latest "daily new cases reported by Sentinel is "The majority were in Orange, who reported a record-breaking 1,371 new cases on Sunday (not including Sunday) for a total of 18,001."   If that daily increase in cases number remains close to that, the total could go over 30,000. (Initial forecast:) Per the source listed in the question current Orange County cases = 12,078.  (7/3/20) From the following source, as of 7/1/20:  "Just in the last 14 days, there have been 7,223 positive cases. Yesterday, there was an increase of 540 cases. Orange County’s average positivity rate is 7.9%." (https://newsroom.ocfl.net/media-advisories/press-releases/2020/06/coronavirus-updates-2/) Starting with the rough estimate of the recently reported 7,223 positive cases (for the county) divided by 14 days = approx. 516 cases/day. Cases in the county and in the state have recently been increasing significantly + not decreasing.  Somewhat conservatively, to start off the forecast: 27 days (until July 30) multiplied by a projected (overall steady) 516 average cases = approximately 14,000 new cases possible by the question's end date. ((Current 12078 + 14000 possible new cases = 26,078.) FWIW, if you (want to) add an arbitrary (county) cases 'increase factor' of 15%, the projected total comes close to 30,000 for the period. (26078 X 1.15 = 29,990. A projected avg. of 593 cases/day.) Will adjust my estimates as necessary. Adding that I believe that virus countermeasures and increased dissemination of pertinent information may generally ramp-up (in the region), especially starting now.
